metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of diamond bearing basalts in the southern margin of the North China Craton
metadata.description: Detailed geochemical analysis of the balustrade basalts has been carried out in this data set, including whole rock major / trace element, Sr nd Pb isotopic analysis, zircon U-Pb dating, Hf isotopic analysis and silicate melt inclusion major / trace element analysis. X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) was used to analyze the main elements, and the data error was less than 5%. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was used to analyze trace elements in the whole rock, and the error of analysis results was less than 5-10%. The classification and genesis of the basalt can be effectively judged by the characteristics of major and trace elements. The whole rock SR nd Pb isotope was measured by mc-icp-ms. the results include 86Sr / 88Sr, 146nd / 144Nd, 206Pb / 204Pb, 207Pb / 204Pb and 208Pb / 204Pb ratios. SR nd Pb isotope can be used as a good tracer of magma source, which can trace the composition of basalt source. Compared with the whole rock composition, silicate melt inclusions captured by early crystallized minerals can represent the most initial melt composition. In this paper, the composition of single melt inclusion was analyzed by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS), and the analysis error was less than 5%. From the composition of melt inclusions, it can be judged that the initial melt of basalt is more refractory. Zircon, as a common accessory mineral, has been widely used in U-Pb dating. LA-ICPMS in-situ analysis technique was used to determine the zircon grains in the balustrade basalts. The dating results indicate that the balustrade basalts were formed in the Jurassic period. Zircon in-situ Hf isotope can effectively trace the source of zircon formation. In this paper, high-resolution Nu plasma II MC-ICP-MS is used to analyze zircon Hf isotope. In the process of analysis, 176hf / 177hf ratios of standard zircon (91500) and Penglai zircon are 0.282301 ± 0.000017(2 σ, N = 15) and 0.282915 ± 0.000014 (2 σ,  18), consistent with previous reports. Hf isotopic analysis results show that there are enriched components. Combined with the whole rock element and isotopic composition, it can be concluded that the balustrade alkaline basalt may be formed by partial melting of the overlying lithospheric mantle due to dehydration and metasomatism of subduction slab.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the data is stored in xlsx format, and its name is 202001 LG basalt Geo. 202001 represents the first set of data in 2020, LG represents balustrade area, basalt represents basalt, and geo represents geochemical data
Data reading mode: data can be read directly by Microsoft Excel and other software.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used for analyzing the geochemical composition of basalts?
Feature Specification.Answer: detailed geochemical analyses, whole-rock major and trace element analysis, X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, data accuracy of less than 5-10%, whole-rock Sr-Nd-Pb isotopes, multi-collector ICP-MS, zircon U-Pb dating, laser ablation ICP-MS, zircon Hf isotopes, high-resolution multi-collector ICP-MS, specific standardized ratios maintained

Quantification.Question: What is the error margin for major element analysis using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry in a dataset related to the geochemistry of diamond-bearing basalts in the southern margin of the North China Craton?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of Sr-Nd-Pb isotopic analysis in geochemical datasets related to basaltic rocks?
Definition.Answer: Sr-Nd-Pb isotopic analysis serves as an effective tracer for determining the source composition of basaltic rocks. These isotopes, analyzed with multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICP-MS), provide valuable information on the magmatic source characteristics and help trace the origin of the basaltic material.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of different isotopic analysis methods help in inferring the geological processes that led to the formation of basalts in the southern margin of the North China Craton?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of Sr-Nd-Pb isotopic analyses can effectively trace the composition of magma sources, indicating the geological processes involved. For example, the isotopic ratios such as 86Sr/88Sr, 146Nd/144Nd, and 206Pb/204Pb provide insights into the source materials and processes like mantle metasomatism or crustal contamination. Hf isotopic analysis of zircon can trace source materials and indicate the addition of enriched components, which combined with whole-rock elements and isotopes, suggest that the basalts may have formed through partial melting of the lithospheric mantle, influenced by dehydration of subducted slabs.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using multiple isotopic analyses such as Sr-Nd-Pb and Hf isotopes on understanding the source composition of mantle-derived rocks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using multiple isotopic analyses like Sr-Nd-Pb and Hf isotopes can provide a comprehensive understanding of the source composition of mantle-derived rocks by offering insights into the magma source characteristics, tracing the origin and evolution of magmatic processes, and indicating the involvement of different mantle components or crustal contributions. These analyses help in identifying the enrichment processes and the geochemical signatures that define the petrogenesis of the rocks.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and procedures are utilized to conduct geochemical analysis and isotopic dating of basalt samples in geological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments such as X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) are used for major element analysis with less than 5% error, while inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) is employed for trace element analysis with an error margin of 5-10%. Multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (MC-ICP-MS) is used for whole-rock Sr-Nd-Pb isotopic analysis, and laser ablation ICP-MS (LA-ICPMS) is utilized for analyzing single melt inclusions and zircon U-Pb dating. High-resolution Nu Plasma II MC-ICP-MS is applied for in-situ zircon Hf isotope analysis.
